awd_titl_txt: CRISP 2.0 Type 2: Collaborative Research: Water and Health Infrastructure Resilience and Learning (WHIRL)
awd_abstract_narration:
Drinking water and public health systems are some of the most critical infrastructures that support human well-being. This Critical Resilient Interdependent Infrastructure Systems and Processes (CRISP) project will provide new insights about how these systems interact with each other and adapt to challenges. The project will also investigate how the public learns about and engages with public health and water systems. The focus will be to assess how a range of disruptions, from routine challenges to large-scale disasters, alter public interactions with these systems. Study data will include interviews with subject matter experts from water utilities and public health agencies. It will also include a national survey to understand how well these US infrastructures can adapt to future challenges. Information gained from project partners and the national survey will be used to identify factors and develop models that can be used to enhance resilience of both systems. This project will advance knowledge that can be applied to promote access to cleaner, safer drinking water for all communities, including socially and economically disadvantaged ones. It will serve the national interest by identifying practices that can be used to improve management for, and communication methods between, water and public health systems, thereby improving the health, prosperity and welfare of communities. Collaborations with the Water Research Foundation (WRF), National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO), American Indian Mothers, Inc. and others, will assist in translating research results to new practices and policies that reduce the burden of disease in vulnerable populations. The project will also provide training to students, including underrepresented minorities, in STEM.

The research will make theoretical contributions in two primary areas. First, it will build upon organizational learning theory as it is manifest from risks, hazard and disruptions in water events and ground this within systems theory and organizational sense-making. Outcomes include new norms, procedures, structures, capacity and technology designed to promote higher reliability and resilience. This will include describing the ways risk, hazards and failures impact public policy agendas and policy learning outcomes. Second, this research will contribute to theoretical work on resilience in critical infrastructure by connecting the social, managerial, and technical frameworks as manifest around water events. Emerging risks with unknown impact include shrinking cities, decaying infrastructure and persistent under-funding. Transformative aspects of the project include creating theoretical models that describe how the relationship of communities to these coupled interdependent systems shapes organizational learning from disruptions, and in turn enacting changes that enhance resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The WHIRL project (1) characterized interactions between drinking water and public health systems, and other stakeholders to identify factors that pose risk and stakeholders perception of risk, (2) developed models that explain how drinking water and public health systems interact and ways that promote resilience, and (3) developed prototype monitoring systems capable of producing actionable outcomes to enhance resilience. Based on interviews with water systems and public health officials who experienced water related challenges and disasters, we expanded disciplinary definitions of resilience to a transdisciplinary conceptualization that extends to both the interactions within and between systems.

Our national survey found a high level of interaction between public water and local health systems, although this is typically limited to fulfilling regulatory requirements. When faced with challenges that may impact public health, approximately half of local water systems indicated that they are more likely to contact their primacy agency – the regulatory body for the Safe Drinking Water Act (SWDA) – rather than their local health department.

Health-based violations signify challenges that might impact public health. We assessed eight years (201-2017) of SDWA violations and found lower rates of health-based violations in water systems controlled by public health (rather than environmental) agencies.  Waterborne disease outbreaks decrease significantly with state and federal expenditures. Infrastructure age, customer racial composition, previous disaster experience, and funding of drinking water systems were factors related to the likelihood of issuing boil water notices (BWNs) during severe weather. Violations and BWNs are risk signals that systems can receive, interpret and respond to, enhancing resilience and protecting health.

Medium-scale events promote coordination among systems, especially when they have a public dimension. A network analysis of drinking water and public health systems identified three distinct subnetworks of emergency response activities. The strength of working relationships between agencies was strongly associated with coordinated emergency responses, coordinated public responses, planning, and technical assistance.

We conducted several tabletop exercises with and to improve coordination between drinking water and public health officials, community members, and others.  Tabletop exercises were found to focus participants on actions likely to enhance resilience. Tabletops are useful tools in enhancing the capacity of public health and water systems to work together and respond to disruptions more effectively.

Project partners consistently reported the need for timely and effective communication. BWNs and annual consumer confidence reports are the most common messages from water systems to consumers. The WHIRL team evaluated BWNs and found they often do not serve the public need for clear risk information. They also do not comply with notification guidelines developed by the US CDC.  Rather, they appear to function primarily as responses to regulatory requirements. Results highlight the importance of creating and maintaining local-level partnerships among government municipalities, journalists, and water authorities, to support effective risk communication.

With the aim of developing early-warning systems and providing residents with continuous access to information, we monitored drinking water, in real-time, in 24 residences in Detroit, Michigan. Access to individualized water quality data positively affected participants’ perceptions of water quality. Through monitoring we were able to estimate overall chlorine decay coefficients, which were similar to those observed in other drinking water systems. Further, modeling revealed recommendations for residents in oversized, aging water systems to flush their water may have negligible impact on the microbiological quality. Participants expressed interest in more frequent monitoring and communication, including actionable data to allow more informed decisions about home water quality management.

Additionally, we developed an automated toolchain designed to process digital images of free chlorine residual test strips taken with mobile phone cameras. This tool sets the stage for tap water consumers and water utilities to gather more frequent measurements, at a higher temporal and spatial resolution than is currently being collected.

A theoretical framework was developed for policy makers that broadens the factors considered when prioritizing resource allocations so that they can be more equitably implemented. This allows policy makers to prioritize communities that have an increased risk of negative health outcomes and would benefit from water system investments.

The WHIRL project provided critical research experiences and training to 6 undergraduates, 17 graduates and 3 post-doctoral fellows. Results were 37 presentations 13 peer-reviewed journal articles and 2 other publications. Additional publications are anticipated.

Results from this work were disseminated to drinking water and public health officials and community members through close collaboration with American Indian Mothers, Inc., American Water Works Association, Association of State Drinking Water Administrators, Hope Village Initiative, National Association of County and City Health Officials, People’s Water Board, Rural Community Assistance Partnership, and Water Research Foundation.
